annotationDatas.title: C5 root
annotationDatas.content: Contributes to the musculocutaneous, axillary, and radial nerves.

annotationDatas.title: C6 root
annotationDatas.content: Contributes to the musculocutaneous, axillary, radial, and median nerves.

annotationDatas.title: Superior trunk
annotationDatas.content: Formed by the convergence of the C5 and C6 roots. Contributes to the lateral and posterior cords.

annotationDatas.title: Anterior division of superior trunk
annotationDatas.content: Contributes to the lateral cord.

annotationDatas.title: Anterior division of middle trunk
annotationDatas.content: Contributes to the lateral cord.

annotationDatas.title: Inferior trunk
annotationDatas.content: Formed by the convergence of the C8 and T1 roots. Contributes to the medial and posterior cords.

annotationDatas.title: Axillary artery
annotationDatas.content: The main artery of the shoulder region. Arises from the subclavian artery, and continues as the brachial artery.

annotationDatas.title: Suprascapular nerve
annotationDatas.content: A large branch of the superior trunk (C5-C6). Essential for external rotation and abduction of the glenohumeral joint.

annotationDatas.title: Posterior cord
annotationDatas.content: The convergence of the posterior divisions of the three trunks. Branches include the radial nerve (C5-T1), the axillary nerve (C5-C6), and others.

annotationDatas.title: Lateral cord
annotationDatas.content: The convergence of the anterior divisions of the superior and middle trunks. Branches include the lateral pectoral nerve (C5-C6), musculocutaneous nerve (C5-C7), and the lateral root of the median nerve (C5-C7).

annotationDatas.title: Medial cord
annotationDatas.content: The continuation of the anterior division of the inferior trunk. Branches include the ulnar nerve (C7-T1), the medial root of the median nerve (C8-T1), and others.

annotationDatas.title: Musculocutaneous nerve
annotationDatas.content: Arises from the lateral cord (C5-C7) to innervate biceps brachii, brachialis, and coracobrachialis. It is the most important nerve for elbow flexion.

annotationDatas.title: "M" Landmark
annotationDatas.content: A common landmark for orienting yourself to the structures of the brachial plexus.

annotationDatas.title: Ulnar nerve (cut)
annotationDatas.content: Arises from the medial cord (C8-T1). Frequently also has a contribution from C7. Innervates parts of the forearm and hand.

annotationDatas.title: Median nerve
annotationDatas.content: Has two roots: -Lateral root (C5-C7). -Medial root (C8-T1). Innervates most forearm flexors and provides sensory and motor innervation to the hand.

annotationDatas.title: Radial nerve
annotationDatas.content: The main terminal branch from the posterior cord (C5-T1). Innervates the posterior aspect of the upper limb. It is the most important nerve for elbow and wrist extension.

annotationDatas.title: Axillary nerve
annotationDatas.content: Arises from the posterior cord (C5-C6). Provides motor innervation to deltoid and teres minor, and supplies the skin on the lateral aspect of the shoulder.

annotationDatas.title: Thoracodorsal nerve (nerve to latissimus dorsi)
annotationDatas.content: Arises from the posterior cord (C6-C8). Innervates the latissimus dorsi.

annotationDatas.title: Brachial artery
annotationDatas.content: The continuation of the axillary artery, and the main artery of the arm.

annotationDatas.title: Ulnar nerve (continued)
annotationDatas.content: Arises from the medial cord (C8-T1). Frequently also has a contribution from C7. Innervates parts of the forearm and hand.
